PARAGRAPH.STRING: is the sixth highest peak in the Teton Range, Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming. The name of
is derived from the Shoshone Native American word meaning "many pinnacles".
is immediately northeast of Grand Teton and the two are separated from one another by the Teton Glacier.

rises more than 5,500 feet (1,675 m) above of Jenny Lake. The 40 mile (64 km) long Teton Range is the youngest mountain chain in the Rocky Mountains, and began their uplift 9 million years ago, during the Miocene. Several periods of glaciation have carved
and the other peaks of the range into their current shapes. Along with a number of other high peaks in the central Teton Range,
is part of what is known as the Cathedral Group, due to the similarity of the peaks to the spires of a cathedral.
